subject: Technology
title: The Cathode Ray Tube: How Old TVs Worked
description: Learn The Cathode Ray Tube: How Old TVs Worked in one minute.

hook.text: For 70 years, every television used a vacuum tube that shot electrons at a glass screen. It was weird and brilliant.

buildup.text: A CRT fires an electron beam at a phosphor-coated screen. The beam scans left to right, top to bottom, 25 to 30 times per second.

discovery.text: Where the beam hits, the phosphor glows. Varying the beam's intensity creates different shades, forming a picture.

twist.text: CRT televisions were heavy, deep, and power-hungry. A 32-inch CRT weighed over 100 pounds.

climax.text: Flat screens killed the CRT by 2010. But for most of TV history, every image you saw was painted by an electron beam.

punchline.text: For 70 years, television was an electron beam painting pictures on glass.

quiz.question: How does a CRT television create an image?
options: By shooting an electron beam at a phosphor-coated screen
